section.title: Introduction
section.para: A HorizonScript file is, at its core, a collection of values that determine the actions and configuration values used to transform a computer from an indeterminate state to a well-known state running Adélie Linux. These values are categorised into keys, which is a logical unit of a value.
This chapter defines and specifies for every valid key for a HorizonScript file: its name, its purpose, its format, and one or more example values with explanations.

section.title: Required Keys
section.para: Each key specified in this section is required to be present in a HorizonScript. If any key from this section is missing, the HorizonScript will be considered invalid and Horizon Runner will not execute it.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The network key determines if the target computer will support networking or not. If the value is true, the computer will support networking, and at least one netaddress key will then be required.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The network key is a Boolean value — valid values are true and false. network must appear exactly once in a HorizonScript.

example.title: The network Key
example.para: This enables networking for the target computer.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The hostname key determines the hostname of the target computer. This key is always required, even when the target computer will not participate in a network. The computer's hostname is used on shell prompts, most window manager launchers, and in log files.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The hostname key is a string value that must contain only alphanumeric characters and optionally one or more '.' characters. If hostname contains one or more '.' characters, all content before the first '.' is considered the hostname, and all content after the first '.' is considered the domain name. hostname must appear exactly once in a HorizonScript.

example.title: The hostname Key — Setting a Host Name
example.para: This sets the hostname of the target computer to gwyn.

example.title: The hostname Key — Setting a Host Name and Domain Name
example.para: This sets the hostname of the target computer to gwyn.foxkit.internal.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The pkginstall key lists the packages that will be installed on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The pkginstall is a space-separated list of APK packages. They must be available in the repositories used during the installation process. pkginstall must appear at least once in a HorizonScript. There is no limit to the number of times pkginstall may be specified; each one will append to the list of packages to install.

example.title: The pkginstall Key — Simple Usage
example.para: This installs the adelie-base-posix, kde, and x11 packages on the target computer.

example.title: The pkginstall Key — Multiple Invocations
example.programlisting: pkginstall adelie-base-posix pkginstall x11 i3wm pkginstall claws-mail
example.para: This installs the adelie-base-posix, x11, i3wm, and claws-mail packages on the target computer. This advanced usage may be useful if you use a templating engine to generate HorizonScript files.

section.title: Optional Keys
section.para: Each key specified in this section may be present in a HorizonScript. This section additionally defines the default value or action taken if the specified key is not present.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The language key determines the default natural language for the target computer. The value of this key will be used to configure the LANG and LC_ALL environment variables, in addition to installing language packs for certain software.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The language key is a string value that specifies a valid locale code. A locale code must match one of the following formats: xx, or xx_YY, or xx_YY.UTF-8, where xx is a valid ISO 639-1 language code, and YY is a valid ISO 3166-1 country code. language may appear at most once in a HorizonScript.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the language key is not present, no setting will be defined for the LANG or LC_ALL environment variables. Most software treats this as either "C.UTF-8" or "en_US.UTF-8". No language packs will be installed for software that supports multiple language; due to English being the de facto language of software engineering, this implies all software will run in English.

example.title: The language Key — Simple Language
example.para: This sets the language of the target computer to Welsh.

example.title: The language Key — Language with Country Localisation
example.para: This sets the language of the target computer to Canadian French.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The keymap key determines the keyboard layout used for input on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The keymap key is a string value that specifies the name of a keyboard layout. Valid keyboard layouts are listed in /etc/console-setup/ckb/rules/xorg.lst under the ! layout heading. keymap may appear at most once in a HorizonScript.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the keymap key is not present, the target computer will use the default keyboard settings from Linux. These settings are architecture-dependent, but almost universally use a US QWERTY-style layout.

example.title: The keymap Key
example.para: This sets the keyboard layout of the target computer to French AZERTY.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The firmware key determines if the target computer will load potentially insecure, proprietary firmware.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The firmware key is a Boolean value — valid values are true and false. firmware may appear at most once in a HorizonScript.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the firmware key is not present, the target computer will not load proprietary firmware. This is to ensure the integrity, security, and reliability of the target computer.

example.title: The firmware Key
example.para: This explicitly disables loading of firmware on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The netaddress key determines the network configuration used on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para:
The netaddress key is a space-separated list of network configuration information:
The kernel interface name. If the interface specified does not exist, the system will issue a soft error (logging the failure but attempting to continue with installation).
The addressing type. Valid values are dhcp for DHCP v4 and v6, slaac for IPv6 Stateless Automatic Address Configuration, and static for Administrator-specified addressing. The list must end here unless the address type specified is static. Any additional items constitute a configuration error and an invalid HorizonScript.
The IP address. The value specified must be a valid IPv4 or IPv6 address.
The prefix or network mask. The value must be either:
A whole number in the range of 1-32 for IPv4 addresses, or 1-64 for IPv6 addresses.
An IPv4 network mask, in the format octet.octet.octet.octet.
Optionally, the default gateway. The value specified must be a valid IP address of the same family as the IP address specified in item 3.
netaddress must not appear unless network is true. If network is true, then netaddress must appear at least once, and may appear up to 255 times per interface.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: There is no default for this key. It is invalid to enable networking and not provide at least one netaddress key.

example.title: The netaddress Key — Simple DHCP
example.para: This configures the target computer to use DHCP on interface eth0.

example.title: The netaddress Key — Static Addressing
example.para: This configures the target computer to use the addresses 2001:db::1337/64 and 198.51.100.37/24 on interface eth0. The default gateways are 2001:db::1 and 198.51.100.1.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The nameserver key determines the DNS server used for name queries on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The nameserver key takes either an IPv4 address or IPv6 address. Any other value is invalid. The nameserver may appear up to four times in a HorizonScript, or be omitted. It is valid to specify nameserver even if network is false, but name queries will not function properly without a network configuration.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the nameserver key is not specified, name queries requiring the DNS will not succeed on the target computer.

example.title: The nameserver Key
example.para: This configures the target computer to use Quad9's public resolver, 2620:fe::fe, for name queries.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The netssid key determines the wireless networking configuration on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para:
The netssid is a space-separated list of wireless networking configuration information:
The kernel interface name. If the interface specified does not exist, the system will issue a soft error (logging the failure but attempting to continue with installation).
The SSID name to connect to. This must be a string value enclosed by ASCII double-quotes ("). System behaviour is undefined if the SSID name contains an ASCII double-quote.
The security type of the SSID. Valid values are none for an open access point, wep for a WEP passphrase, and wpa for a WPA pre-shared key (PSK).
If the security type is not none, the passphrase or pre-shared key. WPA PSKs may be specified in hexadecimal or as a raw string. The remainder of the line will be used verbatim.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the netssid key is not specified, no wireless network configuration will be present on the target computer.

example.title: The netssid Key — Open Network
example.para: This configures the target computer to connect to the access point with name h, with no security.

example.title: The netssid Key — WEP Network
example.para: This configures the target computer to connect to the access point with name Hophop, with the WEP passphrase omgitsarabbit.

example.title: The netssid Key — WPA2 Network
example.programlisting: netssid wlan0 "The New Fox 5G" wpa shh sekrit
example.para: This configures the target computer to connect to the access point with name The New Fox 5G, with the WPA PSK shh sekrit.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The timezone key determines the local time zone on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The timezone key is a string value that must correspond with a valid zoneinfo time zone name. A list of valid time zone names may be found using the following command on any Adélie Linux computer: find /usr/share/zoneinfo. timezone may appear at most once in a HorizonScript.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the timezone key is not specified, the target computer will use UTC (Universal Coordinated Time) as its time zone.

example.title: The timezone Key
example.para: This configures the target computer to use East Africa Time, as observed in Nairobi, Kenya, for the local time zone.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The repository key specifies the location of an APK package repository to use on the target computer. This repository will be used for initial installation, and added to the /etc/apk/repository file on the target computer.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The repository key is a string value which must describe either an absolute local path or a HTTP or HTTPS location on the network. repository may appear up to ten times in a HorizonScript, or be omitted.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para:
If the repository key is not specified, the default repositories for Adélie Linux will be used:
https://distfiles.adelielinux.org/adelie/$VERSION/system
https://distfiles.adelielinux.org/adelie/$VERSION/user
where $VERSION is the version of Adélie Linux being installed. Additionally, if the firmware key is specified and set to true, the https://distfiles.apkfission.net/adelie-$VERSION/nonfree repository will be added. If repository is specified, none of these repositories will be used unless manually specified.

example.title: The repository Key
example.para: This configures the target computer to use the Server Central mirrors.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: The signingkey key specifies a key to trust for APK package repositories.

formalpara.title: Format
formalpara.para: The signingkey key is a string value which must describe either an absolute local path or an HTTPS location on the network. It is not valid to use an HTTP connection for signingkey. signingkey may appear up to ten times in a HorizonScript, or be omitted.

formalpara.title: Default
formalpara.para: If the signingkey key is not specified, the Adélie Linux repository signing key will be used. Additionally, if the firmware key is specified and set to true, the APK Fission signing key will be used. If signingkey is specified, none of these signing keys will be trusted unless manually specified.

example.title: The signingkey Key
example.para: This configures the target computer to use the default Adélie Linux repository signing key, and also a repository signing key that is available for download from the URL https://packages/builder@ourcompany.net.pub.

section.title: Disk Partitioning Keys
section.para: This section describes the keys used for partitioning one or more hard disk drives using HorizonScript. Of these, only the mount key is required to be present in a valid HorizonScript.

formalpara.title: Purpose
formalpara.para: All disk partitioning keys that take a size argument shall follow the format described in this section. There are three forms of valid size that may be specified.

formalpara.title: Format #1: Block Size
formalpara.para: Block sizing format is: number{K|M|G|T}. K, M, G, and T represent IEC binary prefixes; for example, "150G" would specify 150 GiB.

formalpara.title: Format #2: Percentage
formalpara.para: Percentage format is: number%, where number is a number from 1 to 100 inclusive. It is invalid to specify multiple partitions that would use more than 100% of a containing block device.

formalpara.title: Format #3: Fill
formalpara.para: The literal string fill specifies that the partition shall fill the remaining space of the containing block device. No partitions may come after one that specifies fill on the same containing block device.
